intro: Rodigia interrupta, commonly known as the interrupted rodigia, is a flowering plant native to certain regions of North America. It belongs to the family Asteraceae, which includes daisies and sunflowers, and is characterized by its composite flower heads. The plant typically grows in moist, open habitats such as meadows and stream banks. Its leaves are alternate, lance-shaped, and often have a rough texture. Rodigia interrupta produces small, yellowish flowers that bloom in late summer, attracting various pollinators.
